member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Compiler.BuiltinList
member.summary:
A really long list of known Game Maker: Studio constants and variables, taken from code analysis.
Will likely need to be updated on every new Game Maker version with new features.

member.summary: If used for auto-naming temp vars

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.DecompileContext.AlreadyProcessed
member.summary: Set containing already-decompiled child code entries. Used to prevent decompiling the same child entry multiple times. Only applies to function entries, struct and constructors are unaffected.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.DecompileContext.assetTypes
member.summary: Contains the resolved asset type for every variable

member.summary: Contains the result of decompiling this code block. This is a map from an entry point address to a list of statements. Needs to be here to access it in ToString for inline function definitions.

member.summary: Allows to disable the anonymous code name resolution to prevent recursion

member.summary: The value that will be assigned.

member.summary: Whether the destination variable is a struct.

member.summary: Represents all expressions.

member.summary: What type this expression evaluates to.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.Decompiler.Statement
member.summary: Represents all kinds of high-level decompilation results, to be stringified at the end.

member.name: M:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.Decompiler.Statement.ToString(UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.DecompileContext)
member.summary: Creates a string representation of the statement.

member.returns: A string representation of the statement.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.Decompiler.TempVar
member.summary: Represents an unnamed value that gets passed around the stack. Theoretically, these should be cleaned up and removed by the end of decompilation.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.GlobalDecompileContext
member.summary: The DecompileContext is global for the entire decompilation run, or possibly multiple runs. It caches the decompilation results which don't change often to speedup decompilation.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.GlobalDecompileContext.ScriptArgsCache
member.summary: A cache of resolved function argument types. This is kept here because decompiling is slow, and there is no need to do it every time unless the code has changed.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Decompiler.GlobalDecompileContext.AnonymousFunctionNameCache
member.summary: A cache of function to actual name mapping. GMS2.3+ sometimes (usually when dealing with global scripts) calls method functions using the legacy call operator, passing the anonymous function directly. This dictionary contains a map from UndertaleFunction to its actual name, obtained by decompiling the parent CodeObject and looking for the assignment to global variable with function name.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleEmbeddedImage
member.summary:
An embedded image entry in a GameMaker data file. This is GMS2 only.
Not to be confused with the other "embedded" resources, this is a bit different.
member.remarks:
Rough structure: EMBI - stands for "embedded images"? Couldn't figure out how to fill the chunk with any data by editing a project and recompiling... --- <normal FourCC and chunk length found in every chunk>
Int32 - literally just the number 1, always (unknown)
Array of some kind: Int32 - count of items in array
Each item: 32-bit string pointer, some kind of texture page identifier? 32-bit pointer to something relating to a texture page entry?
.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound
member.summary: Sound entry in a data file.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioEntryFlags
member.summary: Audio entry flags a sound entry can use.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioEntryFlags.IsEmbedded
member.summary: Whether the sound is embedded into the data file.
member.remarks:
This should ideally be used for sound effects, but not for music.
The GameMaker documentation also calls this "not streamed" (or "from memory") for when the flag is present, or "streamed" when it isn't.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioEntryFlags.IsCompressed
member.summary: Whether the sound is compressed.
member.remarks: When a sound is compressed it will take smaller memory/disk space. However, this is at the cost of needing to decompress it when it needs to be played, which means slightly higher CPU usage.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioEntryFlags.IsDecompressedOnLoad
member.summary: Whether the sound is decompressed on game load.
member.remarks: When a sound is played, it must be loaded into memory first, which would usually be done when the sound is first used. If you preload it, the sound will be loaded into memory at the start of the game.

member.name: F:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioEntryFlags.Regular
member.summary: Whether this sound uses the "new audio system".
member.remarks: This is default for everything post Game Maker: Studio. The legacy sound system was used in pre Game Maker 8.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Name
member.summary: The name of the sound entry.
member.remarks: This name is used when referencing this entry from code.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Flags
member.summary: The flags the sound entry uses.
member.remarks: These effectively control different options of this sound.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Type
member.summary: The file format of the audio entry.
member.remarks:
This includes the . from the file extension. Possible values are:
.wav
.mp3
.ogg

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.File
member.summary: The original file name of the audio entry.
member.remarks: This is the full filename how it was loaded in the project. This will be used if the sound effect is streamed from disk to find the sound file.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Effects
member.summary: A pre-Game Maker: Studio way of having certain effects on a sound effect.
member.remarks: The exact way this works is unknown. But following values are possible: Chorus, Echo, Flanger, Reverb, Gargle, all possible to be combined with one another.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Volume
member.summary: The volume the audio entry is played at.
member.remarks: The volume is a number between 0 and 1, which mean "completely silent" and "full volume" respectively.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Preload
member.summary: Whether the sound is decompressed on game load.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.Pitch
member.summary: The pitch change of the audio entry.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioGroup
member.summary: The audio group this audio entry belongs to.
member.remarks: These can only be used with the regular audio system.

member.name: P:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleSound.AudioFile
member.summary: The reference to the audio file.
member.remarks:
This is a UTMT-specific attribute.
All sound entries always have to have a reference to an entry. Even if the sound entry is not embedded, it is still necessary. For that case, you can just link to any embedded sound.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleTextureGroupInfo
member.summary: A texture group info entry in a data file.
member.remarks:
This is a new chunk since Bytecode 17. It's probably related to performance improvements mentioned in the release notes for that runtime. Here is the specification:
TGIN structure - likely stands for Texture Group Info Chunk introduced in 2.2.1 with new texture functions ---
Int32 - probably chunk format version number, always 1
PointerList<T> structure. Each item represents a texture group: 32-bit string pointer - Name 32-bit pointer #1 32-bit pointer #2 32-bit pointer #3 32-bit pointer #4 32-bit pointer #5
#1 leads here: SimpleList<int> of texture page IDs the group has
#2 leads here: SimpleList<int> of sprite IDs the group has
#3 leads here: SimpleList<int> of Spine sprite IDs (normal sprite ID, just this has Spine sprites separated) the group has
#4 leads here: SimpleList<int> of font IDs the group has
#5 leads here: SimpleList<int> of tileset IDs the group has
.

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Models.UndertaleTexturePageItem
member.summary: A texture page item in a data file.
member.remarks:
The way a texture page item works is:
It renders in a box of size x at some position.
, , and are relative to the bounding box, anything outside of that is just transparent.
, , and are part of the texture page which are drawn over , , , .

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.Scripting.ScriptException
member.summary:
The exception that is thrown when trivial errors happen during runtime of UndertaleModTool scripts.
This exception does not contain a stacktrace and should more be handled like an error message that stops execution of the currently running script.

example.code: if (Data is null) throw new ScriptException("Please load data.win first!);

member.name: T:UndertaleModLib.UndertaleData
member.summary: An object representing a Game Maker: Studio data file.
member.remarks:
This is basically the heart of the data file, which is usually named data.win, data.unx, data.ios or data.droid, depending for which OS the game was compiled for..
It includes all the data within it accessible by either the -Chunk attribute, but also via already organized attributes such as or . TODO: add more documentation about how a data file works at one point.
